channel.title: Evolution of jazz
channel.description:
Jazz historian Nat Hentoff presents a series that traces the history of jazz, from its musical and cultural roots to its contemporary forms.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Kansas City, part one
item.description: This program focuses on the strain of jazz that emerged from Kansas City.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Instruments in New Orleans jazz, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two, explores the variety of instruments that New Orleans musicians used when jazz was emerging.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region II: The South

item.title: Bix Beiderbecke, part one
item.description: This program focuses on Bix Beiderbecke, the jazz cornetist, pianist, and composer.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Bop instrumentation, part one
item.description: This program continues to look at the elements of bop, particularly the instrumentation common in the genre.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Influences merging, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two parts, explores the continued merging of the various influences that lay at the foundation of jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Extended form in contemporary jazz continued, part one
item.description: This program continues the exploration of the usage of extended form in jazz improvisation and composition.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Bop instrumentation, part two
item.description: This program continues to look at the elements of bop, particularly the instrumentation common in the genre.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Jazz on the Eastern seaboard, part two
item.description: This program discusses the spread of jazz to the Eastern seaboard.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Sociology

item.title: Origin of the blues, part two
item.description: This program, the second of two parts, explores the origin of the blues, a crucial building block for jazz music.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Bop, part two
item.description: The second part of this program talks about bop and its place in the history of jazz. Trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie is focused upon.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Fats Waller, part one
item.description: This program continues to explore the music and influence of Fats Waller.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Waller, Fats, 1904-1943. Works. Selections

item.title: Duke Ellington continued, part two
item.description: This program is a continuation of the focus on the music of Duke Ellington.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Kansas City, part two
item.description: This program focuses on the strain of jazz that emerged from Kansas City.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Duke Ellington continued, part one
item.description: This program is a continuation of the focus on the music of Duke Ellington.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Series wrap up, part two
item.description: The series concludes with an overview of what Hentoff didn't cover in previous programs.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: U.S. Literature

item.title: Collective improvisation and cool jazz, part two
item.description: This program explores the growth of collective improvisation in jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Count Basie, part two
item.description: This program focuses on the music of Count Basie.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Swing, part one
item.description: This program talks about swing and what it means within the parameters of jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Swing (Music)--History and criticism

item.title: Dave Brubeck, part one
item.description: This program focuses on the music of pianist Dave Brubeck.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Hot jazz, part two
item.description: This program talks about the resurgence of hot jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Southern States

item.title: Early New York jazz, part two
item.description: This program discusses the emergence of jazz in New York, focusing on Fats Waller.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: New York (State)--New York

item.title: Extended form in contemporary jazz continued, part two
item.description: This program continues the exploration of the usage of extended form in jazz improvisation and composition.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Origin of the blues, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two parts, explores the origin of the blues, a crucial building block for jazz music.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Transition into modern jazz, part one
item.description: This program looks at the shift that occurred during the 1940s toward bop, a newer form of jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: U.S. History (1900-present)

item.title: Duke Ellington, part two
item.description: This program focuses on the music of Duke Ellington.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Introduction, part two
item.description: The second part of the opening program in this series discusses aspects of African music, which was crucial to the early development of jazz.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Jazz in the 30s and 40s, part two
item.description: This program looks at more jazz figures from the 1930s and 1940s, such as Lionel Hampton and Mary Lou Williams.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Williams, Mary Lou, 1910-1981

item.title: Boogie woogie and the beginnings of ragtime, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two parts, explores boogie woogie music.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Jazz in the 30s and 40s, part one

item.dc:subject: Williams, Mary Lou, 1910-1981

item.description: This program focuses on the music of Duke Ellington.

item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.description: This program explores the Afro-Cuban influence on jazz.

item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.title: Series wrap up, part one
item.description: The series concludes with an overview of what Hentoff didn't cover in previous programs.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: U.S. Literature

item.title: Growth of jazz, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two, explores the growth of jazz, as it begins to form in various cities around the U.S. and, particularly, in New Orleans.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Chicago jazz, part one
item.description: This program, the first of two parts, continues the discussion of the spread of jazz north from New Orleans into the U.S. midwest.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: Travel & Leisure

item.title: Introduction, part one
item.description: The first part of the opening program in this series discusses the differences between jazz music and the more established concepts derived from the European classical tradition.
item.dc:creator: Hentoff, Nat
item.dc:subject: NAEB Region I: The Northeast

item.description: This program goes further in depth about the major changes occuring in jazz during the late 1940s and into the early 1950s.
